title: END: Early Noise Dropping for Efficient and Effective Context Denoising
author: Hongye Jin (Texas A&M University), Pei Chen (Amazon), Jingfeng Yang (Amazon), Zhengyang Wang (Amazon), Meng Jiang (University of Notre Dame), Yifan Gao (Amazon), Binxuan Huang (Amazon), ..., Bing Yin (Amazon)
relevance_why: The proposed method, Early Noise Dropping (END), aims to improve context processing in Large Language Models (LLMs), which is closely related to optimizing models for applications in audio and speech processing where noise significantly degrades quality.
background: Improving the quality of outputs from Large Language Models by mitigating distractions caused by irrelevant or noisy contextual information.
contribution: This paper introduces Early Noise Dropping (END) to solve the issue of irrelevant context noise in LLMs, achieving significantly improved performance and efficiency without requiring fine-tuning.
technical_comparison: Previous methods either needed complex multi-agent systems or additional training, which increased computational demands. This work improves by leveraging inherent noise discrimination in LLMs to filter input early and reduce computation.
key_innovation: Utilizes a linear prober to assess and discard noisy input chunks based on the model's early-layer representations, thus optimizing processing efficiency and accuracy.
real_world_impact: Has the potential to enhance LLM applications in various fields by ensuring outputs are generated based on relevant information, thus increasing their reliability and utility. No immediate real-world impact if theoretical aspects are not validated.
limitations: The reliance on a linear prober may limit generalization to more complex tasks and contexts, and further exploration into sophisticated probing approaches is suggested.

new_terms.Early Noise Dropping (END): **Early Noise Dropping (END)** is a method designed to identify and eliminate irrelevant context in inputs to Large Language Models early in their processing pipeline.
new_terms.linear prober: **Linear prober** refers to a linear classifier that is used to assess the relevance of input chunks during processing.
